Key Findings

  • 87 contracts published after their award date (average 27.3 days late, worst case: 322 days)
  • 7 contracts with weak competition indicators (short tender periods or rapid awards)
  • 9 contracts showing potential threshold avoidance (87-99.9% of procurement thresholds)
  • 2 category monopolies: Pick Everard in civil engineering, Field & Lawn in marquees

Late Publications

Publishing contract notices after the contract has already been awarded undermines the purpose of transparency. When a contract is published 322 days late, any opportunity for competitive challenge has long passed.

Of Chorley's 111 awarded contracts on the Contracts Finder portal, 87 were published after their award date. While some delays may reflect administrative backlogs, the scale suggests systemic issues with procurement transparency.

Category Monopolies

Two suppliers hold monopoly positions in their respective categories: Pick Everard is the sole supplier for civil engineering services, while Field & Lawn is the sole provider of marquees and temporary structures. While this doesn't necessarily indicate poor practice, single-supplier categories warrant periodic market testing.
